sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'ma'
sentence.text: Ma Maria ben abi bere.
sentence.gloss: But Mary was pregnant.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'sanede'
sentence.text: Sanede yu naki a dagu?
sentence.gloss: Why did you hit the dog?

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'sanede'
sentence.text: A boi no taigi mi fu sanede a naki a dagu.
sentence.gloss: The boy didn’t tell me why he hit the dog.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'san'
sentence.text: San yu e kon du dyaso?
sentence.gloss: What have you come here for?

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'san'
sentence.text: Mi no sabi san a boi kon fu du.
sentence.gloss: I don’t know what the boy has come here for.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'di'
sentence.text: A man di gi mi a papira no taigi mi san fu du nanga en.
sentence.gloss: The man who gave me the paper didn’t tell me what to do with it.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'di'
sentence.text: Di mi ben e sribi, a fufuruman kon na ini a oso.
sentence.gloss: While I was sleeping the thief came in the house

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'baya'
sentence.text: Baya, tamara yu no mu kon.
sentence.gloss: Listen, don’t come tomorrow.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'yèrè'
sentence.text: Tide mi no o kon na yu oso, yèrè!
sentence.gloss: I’m not coming to your house today, ya hear!

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'no'
sentence.text: A film ben span, no?
sentence.gloss: The movie was exciting, wasn’t it?

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'fu'
sentence.text: A oto na fu en.
sentence.gloss: The car is his.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'fu'
sentence.feature: First 'fu' as subordinating conjunction, second as possessive
sentence.text: Fu di mi mu wasi den krosi fu mi, meki mi no man gwe.
sentence.gloss: Because I’ve got to wash my clothes, I can’t go

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'fu'
sentence.text: Den bigiman e kon makandra fu taki a moni tori.
sentence.gloss: The leaders come together (in order) to discuss the money situation.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'fu'
sentence.feature: First 'fu' as possessive, second as preposition
sentence.text: A granman fu den Dyuka kmopo fu Dritabiki.
sentence.gloss: The chief of the Aukaners comes from Drietabbetje

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'fu'
sentence.text: Mi bai pinda fu a frow dati.
sentence.gloss: I bought peanuts from that lady.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'gi'
sentence.text: Go bai wan brede gi mi.
sentence.gloss: Вuy some bread for me.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'gi'
sentence.text: A bon disi no e gi bun nyanyan.
sentence.gloss: This tree does not produce good fruit.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'pe'
sentence.text: Mi e tan pe a skowtu-oso de.
sentence.gloss: I live where the police station is.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'pe'
sentence.text: Mi no go no wan pe.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'pe'
sentence.text: Pe yu e go?
sentence.gloss: Where are you going?

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'misrefi'
sentence.text: Mi gi misrefi mankeri di mi ben e kapu den taki.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'ensrefi'
sentence.text: A gi ensrefi mankeri.
sentence.gloss: He injured himself.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'wisrefi'
sentence.text: Efu wi e tan feti so doro, wi o kiri wisrefi.
sentence.gloss: If we keep fighting like this, we will destroy ourselves.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'en'
sentence.text: A dagu e leki en soro futu.
sentence.gloss: The dog is licking its sore paw.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'en'
sentence.text: En na mi basi.
sentence.gloss: He is my boss.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'fosi'
sentence.text: Mi na a fosi pikin fu mi mama.
sentence.gloss: I am my mother’s first child.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'fosi'
sentence.text: Fosi mi go drape, mi mus du wan sani.
sentence.gloss: Before I go there I have to do something

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'musu'
sentence.text: Ala den mama mus tyari den pikin fu go teki spoiti.
sentence.gloss: Every mother should take her children to get vaccinated.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'alamala'
sentence.text: Un alamala o go tide na foto.
sentence.gloss: We are all going to town today.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'srefi'
sentence.text: Yu srefi sabi a sani dati, san wani taki yu lan.
sentence.gloss: You yourself know what it means to be paralyzed.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'srefi'
sentence.text: Ala dei na den srefi sma e kon ferferi unu.
sentence.gloss: Every day the same people come and bother us.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'srefi'
sentence.text: Na en srefi ben mus du ala sani.
sentence.gloss: He himself had to do everything.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'na'
sentence.text: Den tu man na skowtu.
sentence.gloss: The two men are policemen.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'na'
sentence.text: Mi e go na mi mama oso.
sentence.gloss: I’m going to my mother’s house. Mi de na mi mama. I’m at my mother’s.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'na'
sentence.text: Na kon yu e kon fu teki a moni kba?
sentence.gloss: You’ve come already to take the money?

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'na'
sentence.text: Na yu fufuru mi moni!
sentence.gloss: You (emp) stole my money!

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'na'
sentence.text: Na drape un mus go.
sentence.gloss: We must go there (emp)

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'na'
sentence.text: Mi de na mi mama.
sentence.gloss: I’m at my mother’s.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'na di'
sentence.text: Na di den dagu bari so mi no kon ini a dyari.
sentence.gloss: Because the dogs barked so, I didn’t come in the yard.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'ini'
sentence.text: A bedi de na ini a kamra.
sentence.gloss: The bed is in the (bed)room.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'ini'
sentence.text: Yu no e kon na ini?
sentence.gloss: Aren’t you coming inside?

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'de'
sentence.text: A owru de baka a doro.
sentence.gloss: The machete is behind the door.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'tapu'
sentence.text: A nyanyan de tapu a tafra.
sentence.gloss: The food is on the table.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'tapu'
sentence.text: Yu mu tapu den pikin meki den no prei na strati.
sentence.gloss: You must keep the children from playing in the street

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'kba'
sentence.text: A pasi kba dya.
sentence.gloss: The path ends here.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'owru'
sentence.text: Mi e owru kba.
sentence.gloss: I’m getting old already

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'abra'
sentence.text: Den plane no mag frei abra a foto.
sentence.gloss: Planes are not allowed to fly over the city.

sentence.source: Wilner
sentence.text: Mi go nanga mi brada na foto.
sentence.gloss: I went with my brother to town.

sentence.source: Wilner
sentence.text: Boiki papa ben prani gruntu èn a ben kweki fowru nanga wan kaw.
sentence.gloss: Boiki’s father grew vegetables, and he raised chickens and a cow.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'moro'
sentence.text: Poti moro watra ini a embre.
sentence.gloss: Put more water in the bucket.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'moro'
sentence.text: Mi brada moro langa.
sentence.gloss: My brother is taller.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'psa'
sentence.text: Mi brada langa psa tu meter.
sentence.gloss: My brother is taller than two meters.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'psa'
sentence.text: Un psa a broki kba.
sentence.gloss: We’ve already passed the bridge.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'moro'
sentence.text: Fa a alen kon mi no ben man kon moro.
sentence.gloss: Because of the rain, I couldn’t come anymore.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'dati'
sentence.text: Na a boi dati kon fufuru ini mi oso.
sentence.gloss: That is the boy who came and stole from my house.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'dati'
sentence.text: Den boi taki dati den o kon tamara baka.
sentence.gloss: The boys said that they would come back tomorrow.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'taki'
sentence.text: Yu denki taki yu o man du en?
sentence.gloss: Do you think that you can do it?

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'ibri'
sentence.text: Ibri bon san no e gi bun froktu, den o kapu trowe.
sentence.gloss: Every tree that does not give good fruit, they will chop down

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'pikinso'
sentence.text: A fufuruman gwe nanga a pikinso moni san mi ben kibri.
sentence.gloss: The thief ran off with the little money that I had set aside.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'pinkinso'
sentence.text: Mi o skreki en pikinso gi yu.
sentence.gloss: I’ll warm it up a little for you.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'son'
sentence.text: Yu no e ferstan son sani te bigisma taki.
sentence.gloss: You don’t understand some things when old people speak.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'ipi'
sentence.text: Mi abi ipi krosi fu wasi.
sentence.gloss: We have got a lot of clothes to wash

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'back'
sentence.text: Mi baka e hati mi!
sentence.gloss: My back is killing me!

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'baka'
sentence.text: Fosi yu stofu a fowru, baka en pikinso.
sentence.gloss: Before you braise the chicken, you need to fry it a little

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'baka'
sentence.text: Den sneisi e kibri sukru baka a toonbangi.
sentence.gloss: The Chinese (shopkeepers) hide sugar behind the counter.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'baka'
sentence.text: Efu yu e naki a boi baka, mi o fon yu.
sentence.gloss: If you hit the boy again, I’ll beat you.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'dyarusu'
sentence.text: A pikin disi na wan dyarusu pikin.
sentence.gloss: This child is a jealous child.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'bere'
sentence.text: A boi disi abi wan langa bere.
sentence.gloss: Тhis boy has an insatiable appetite.

sentence.source: Wilner John (2007), Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary. SIL International. From entry 'kefalek'
sentence.text: Na wan kefalek sani a boi disi du.
sentence.gloss: It was an exceptional thing that this boy did.
